Cultists of certain antediluvian societies have discovered a method through which a shoggoth can be bought to the Material Plane, though even they are cautious to do so.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny eel. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

trait.name: Antimagic Susceptibility
entries: The swarm is {@condition incapacitated} while in the area of an antimagic field. If targeted by dispel magic, the swarm must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against the caster's spell save DC or fall {@condition unconscious} for 1 minute.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the swarm remains motionless and isn't flying, it is indistinguishable from a normal set of books.

trait.name: Spell Storing
entries: A spellcaster who creates a swarm of spellbooks can cause the sawrm to store one {@filter spell of 4th level or lower|spells|level=0;1;2;3;4}. To do so, the creator must cast the spell on the swarm. The spell has no effect but is stored within the swarm. When commanded to do so by the creator or when a situation arises that was predefined by the spellcaster, the swarm casts the stored spell with any parameters set by the original caster, requiring no material components. When the spell is cast or a new spell is stored, any previous spell is lost.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 0 ft., one creature in the swarm's space. {@h}5 ({@damage 2d4}) bludgeoning damage, or 2 ({@damage 1d4}) bludgeoning damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer.

If a wizard wants to protect a library or study as against intruders, they might enchant a dozen or more spellbooks to animate when someone who is not their owner enters a room or starts plundering the shelves. A particularly clever wizard might even inscribe a spell into the books that they can cast at their creators command, or when a predefined situation arises.

entries.name: Constructed Nature
entries: A swarm of spellbooks doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.
The process of creating a swarm of spellbooks is really quite simple. Containing them on the other hand...

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The tribute gatherer can breathe only underwater.

action.name: Tentacles
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is Medium or smaller, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}) and {@condition restrained} until the grapple ends. The tribute gatherer can grapple two targets in this way.

action.name: Tentacle Slam
entries: The tribute gatherer slams creatures {@condition grappled} by it into each other or a solid surface. Each creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or take 11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage and be {@condition stunned} until the end of the tribute gatherer's next turn. On a successful save, the target takes half the bludgeoning damage and isn't {@condition stunned}.

In Waterdeep's Deepwater Harbour lies an underwater dungeon where giant, fiendish octopi gather up offerings given to the Bitch Queen and fling them through a portal to her domain. These creatures are known only as tribute gatherers and resemble a giant green octopus with horns protruding from its knobbly skin and glowing amber eyes.

monster.name: Uchuulon
languages: understands Deep Speech but can't speak

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The uchuulon can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Paralyzing Slime
entries: A creature that touches the uchuulon or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. Until this poison ends, the target is {@condition paralyzed}. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

trait.name: Sense Magic
entries: THe uchuulon senses magic within 120 feet of it at will. This trait otherwise works like the {@spell detect magic} spell but isn't itself magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The uchuulon makes two pincer attacks. If the uchuulon is grappling a creature, the uchuulon can also use its tentacles once.

action.name: Pincer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5}, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage. The target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 13}) if it is a Large or smaller creature and the uchuulon doesn't have two other creatures {@condition grappled}.

action.name: Tentacles
entries: One creature {@condition grappled} by the uchuulon must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. Until this poison ends, the target is {@condition paralyzed}. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

A uchuulon, sometimes known as a slime chuul, is a {@creature chuul} implanted with an illithid tadpole. They are used by illithids as hunters and guardians. The process of ceremorphos that creates a uchuulon kills the tadpole, and transforms the chuul into a blue, slime-covered mockery of its old form. The slime which covers a uchuulon is similar to that secreted by a chuul's tentacles.

trait.name: Detect Life
entries: The urophion can magically sense the presence of living creatures up to 5 miles away. It knows the general direction they're in but not their exact locations.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the urophion remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a normal cave formation, such as a stalagmite.

trait.name: Grasping Tendrils
entries: The urophion can have up to six tendrils at a time. Each tendril can be attacked (AC 20; 10 hit points; immunity to poison and psychic damage). Destroying a tendril deals no damage to the urophion, which can extrude a replacement tendril on its next turn. A tendril can also be broken if a creature takes an action and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Strength check against it.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The urophion can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The urophion's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 13}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The urophion makes four attacks with its tendrils, uses Reel, and makes one attack with its bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 4d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Tendril
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 50 ft., one creature. {@h}The target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). Until the grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained} and has disadvantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws, and the urophion can't use the same tendril on another target.

action.name: Reel
entries: The urophion pulls each creature {@condition grappled} by it up to 25 ft. straight toward it.

action.name: Mind Blast (1/Day)
entries: The urophion magically emits psychic energy in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must succeed on a {@dc 13} Intelligence saving throw or be {@condition stunned} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

An urophion is a truly unique creature, and is evidence of the willingness of the illithid to attempt to create ceremorphs from the most unlikely organisms. Urophions are nearly identical to {@creature roper|mm|ropers} in all physical aspects, though they are just as intelligent as mind flayers with similar psionic abilities, and uniquely powerful sense of life detection.

trait.name: Limited Amphibiousness
entries: The vodyanoi can breathe air and water, but it needs to be submerged at least once every 4 hours to avoid suffocating.

trait.name: Slippery
entries: The vodyanoi has advantage on ability checks and saving throws made to escape a grapple.

trait.name: Tunneler
entries: The vodyanoi can burrow through solid rock at half its burrowing speed and leaves a 10-foot-wide, 15-foot-high tunnel in its wake.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vodyanoi makes three attacks: two with its claws and one with its mandibles.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Mandibles
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Regurgitate Eels (1/Day)
entries: The vodyanoi can regurgitate a {@creature swarm of lightning eels|CallfromtheDeep} which appears in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of it. The swarm acts on its own initiative count. If the vodyanoi hasn't used this trait when it dies, a {@creature swarm of lightning eels|CallfromtheDeep} erupts from its corpse at the start of its next turn. The swarm acts on its own initiative count.

These aquatic predators are closely related to the {@creature umber hulk}. They are similar in appearance to umber hulks but are almost twice the size, have webbed claws, and have only one pair of eyes, and thus lack the ability to confuse opponents. Vodyanoi skin is green and slimy to the touch, but beneath it is a thick, knobbly hide. Vodyanoi prey on all manner of marine life but prefer the taste of humanoid flesh. They have learned to rend the hulls of large ships and capsize smaller ones to get to their favourite prey. Perhaps the most peculiar feature of the vodyanoi is its stomach. Rather than digest its own food, the vodyanoi cultivates a small population of eels in its stomach, which it can regurgitate if necessary to help bring down prey

walk.condition: (0 ft., swim 40 ft. in shark form)

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't silvered

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: The wereshark can use its action to polymorph into a sharj-humanoid hybrid or into a {@creature hunter shark}, or back into its true form, which is humanoid. Its statistics, other than its AC, are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The wereshark has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Amphibious (Hybrid Form Only)
entries: The wereshark can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Water Breathing (Shark Form Only)
entries: The wereshark can only breathe underwater.

action.name: Multiattack (Humanoid or Hybrid Form Only)
entries: The wereshark makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its spear.

action.name: Bite (Shark or Hybrid Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage. If the target is a humanoid, it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or be cursed with wereshark lycanthropy.

action.name: Spear (Humanoid or Hybrid Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage, or 8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.

variant.name: Nonhuman Lycanthropes
entries: The statistics presented in this section assume a base creature of human. However, you can also use the statistics to represent nonhuman lycanthropes, adding verisimilitude by allowing a nonhuman lycanthrope to retain one or more of its humanoid racial traits. For example, an elf werewolf might have the Fey Ancestry trait.

Weresharks are ruthless in the pursuit of prey. In their humanoid form they are aggressive loners, making their homes in sea caves and deserted fishing hamlets. In shark form they act as any shark would, always on the lookout for an easy meal. Like a werewolf, a wereshark can wield weapons in its hybrid form, but prefers to tear foes apart with its gaping, many-toothed maw.

entries.name: Player Characters as Lycanthropes
entries: A character who becomes a lycanthrope retains his or her statistics except as specified by lycanthrope type. The character gains the lycanthrope's speeds in nonhumanoid form, damage immunities, traits, and actions that don't involve equipment. The character is proficient with the lycanthrope's natural attacks, such as its bite or claws, which deal damage as shown in the lycanthrope's statistics. The character can't speak while in animal form.

A humanoid hit by an attack that carries the curse of lycanthropy must succeed on a Constitution saving throw (DC 8 + the lycanthrope's proficiency bonus + the lycanthrope's Constitution modifier) or be cursed. If the character embraces the curse, his or her alignment becomes the one defined for the lycanthrope. The DM is free to decide that a change in alignment places the character under DM control until the curse of lycanthropy is removed.

entries.name: Wereshark
entries: The character gains a Strength of 18 if his or her score isn't already higher, and a +1 bonus to AC while in shark or hybrid form (from natural armour). Attack and damage rolls for the bite are based on Strength. The wereshark also gains the Amphibious and Water Breathing traits.

monster.name: Zombie Dragon Turtle
languages: understands Aquan and Draconic, but can't speak

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the zombie dragon turtle to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the zombie drops to 1 hit point instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The zombie dragon turtle makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws. It can make one tail attack in place of its two claw attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 3d12 + 7}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d8 + 7}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 3d12 + 7}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 20} Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 10 feet away from the dragon turtle and knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Freezing Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The zombie dragon turtle exhales frozen air in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw, taking 52 ({@damage 15d6}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Spew Zombies (1/Day)
entries: The zombie dragon turtle disgorges {@dice 3d4} normal {@creature zombie|mm|zombies}, which appear in unoccupied spaces within 15 feet of it. The disgorged zombies act on their own initiative count. If the zombie dragon turtle has not used this attack when it dies, {@dice 3d4} normal {@creature zombie|mm|zombies} erupt from its corpse at the start of its next turn. These zombies act on their own initiative count.

A powerful necromancer can use dark rituals to zombify almost any creature. The Curse of Irphong is such a dragon turtle which has been animated by the {@creature Tulkhan|CallfromtheDeep|necromancer of Irphong} and is used to attack ships that travel through Asavir's Channel.

entries.name: Age
entries: Merfolk mature at the same rate as humans and have lifespans similar in length to theirs.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Merfolk society holds individual freedom very highly, with a weak hierarchical structure. As such, they tend toward neutral alignments.

entries.name: Size
entries: Merfolk are around six feet tall including their tails, and weigh between 200 and 250 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 10 feet, and you have a swimming speed of 30 feet.

entries.name: Amphibious
entries: You can breathe air and water.

entries.name: Deep Sea Survivors
entries: You're naturally gifted in survival techniques, especially underwater. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Perception} and {@skill Survival} skills, and ignore any drawbacks caused by an underwater environment.

entries.name: Mercantile Culture
entries: Merfolk culture is frequently based around trading with surface dwellers. Because of this, merfolk gain a knack for trade. You add your proficiency bonus to checks made to bargain and communicate with merchants and traders.

entries.name: Underwater Weapons Training
entries: You gain proficiency with the {@item spear|phb}, {@item javelin|phb}, and {@item trident|phb}. Ranged attacks with these weapons don't automatically miss a target beyond their normal range while underwater.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Aquan.

Merfolk are aquatic humanoids with the upper body of a human and the lower body of a fish. They are common throughout the oceans of the Forgotten Realms, and their settlements are as varied in colour, culture and outlook as the human races of the surface. Most merfolk communities are semi-nomadic, as the aquatic folk lack the skills to forge metal or carve stone. Instead, their settlements are founded in undersea caverns, coral mazes, and sunken cities.

Many merfolk communities survive by trading with other undersea communities, such as tritons and sea elves. Because craft and trade is part of almost all merfolk cultures, these folk are renowned for their ability to barter with the best merchants of the realms.

entries.name: Merfolk Names
entries: Merfolk names are not dissimilar to human names in sound and flow, though sometimes contain more vowel sounds to make them easier to pronounce beneath the waves. Merfolk family names are passed down either the matriarchal or patriarchal line, depending on the culture.

items.name: Male Names:
items.entry: Elliros, Berriamo, Lharo, Pahua, Uthario

items.name: Female Names:
items.entry: Antinua, Elhara, Nissailin, Seraphima

items.name: Family Names:
items.entry: Greatwave, Pearlswell, Redcoral, Reefsilver, Southsea

entries.name: Age
entries: Sahuagin reach adulthood at 12 and live up to 50 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Most sahuagin are bloodthirsty raiders who claim dominion over the ocean. Those who are brutal rise to the top in a regimented, militocratic society. They are usually lawful evil.

entries.name: Size
entries: Sahuagin are usually over 6 feet tall and weigh between 200 and 250 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 30 feet, and you have a swimming speed of 40 feet.

entries.name: Limited Amphibiousness
entries: You can breathe air and water, but need to be submerged at least once every 4 hours to avoid suffocating.

entries.name: Shark Telepathy
entries: You can magically communicate with any shark within 120 feet of you, using a limited telepathy which doesn't allow the shark to reply. You can cast {@spell dominate beast} once per day, but only on sharks.

entries.name: Underwater Adaptation
entries: You ignore any drawbacks caused by an underwater environment.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Sahuagin. Sahuagin is a gutteral, snarling language used almost exclusively within sahuagin society.

entries.name: Age
entries: Sea spawn are humans that have been transformed by the kraken Slarkrethel. They are always over 60, and can live up to 120 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Due to the corruption of the kraken, sea spawn are almost always evil.

entries.name: Size
entries: Sea spawn are similar in stature to humans. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 20 feet, and you have a swimming speed of 30 feet.

entries.name: Limited Amphibiousness
entries: You can breathe air and water, but need to be submerged in the sea at least once a day for 1 minute to avoid suffocating.

entries.name: Telepathic Resistance
entries: You have resistance to psychic damage. In addition, you are immune to magic that allows other creatures to read your thoughts, determine whether you are lying, know your alignment, or know your creature type. Creatures can telepathically communicate with you only if you allow it.

entries.name: Piscine Anatomy
entries: Part of you has been transformed through mutation. The DC for the mutations is 8 + your Constitution modifier + your proficiency bonus. Choose one of the following:

items.name: Mouth.
items.entry: You have a shark-like mouth which you can use to make unarmed strikes. If you hit with it, you deal piercing damage equal to {@dice 1d6} + yuor Strength modifier.

items.name: Hair.
items.entry: You have poisonous quills instead of hair which you can use to make unarmed strikes. If you hit with it, you deal {@dice 1d6} poison damage. A creature hit by the atack must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute.

items.name: Arm.
items.entry: One of your arms is transformed into a tentacle, which you can use to make unarmed strikes. If you hit with it, you deal bludgeoning damage equal to {@dice 1d4} plus your Strength modifier. A Medium or smaller creature hit by the attack is {@condition grappled} (see escape DC above). Until this grapple ends, you can't grapple another target with your tentacle.

entries.name: Underwater Adaption
entries: You ignore any drawbacks caused by an underwater environment.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Aquan and Common.

In the Forgotten Realms, sea spawn are natives of a string of islands called Purple Rocks. The Rocklanders venerate the kraken Slarkrethel by throwing their newborns into the ocean, where they are claimed by the King of the Trackles Depths. The infants undergo a magical transformation that turns them into sea pawn, though they rarely manifest their mutations until old age. When the mutation occurs, their anatomy warps into a horrifying manifestation of the deep; barnacle covered skin, coral spurs sprouting from limbs, shark-like mouths, the variety of mutation seems endless.
While most sea spawn venerate their creator after transformation, some turn against Slarkrethel for what it has done to them, seeking revenge against their old master

entries.name: Sea Spawn Names
entries: Sea Spawn don't take a new name when they undergo their transformation, meaning that those from Purple Rocks, where the majority are found, have Illuskan names.

entries.name: Age
entries: Aldani mature at the same rate as humans, but can live up to twice as long, around 200 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Aldani live in peaceful societies that follow strict, non-violent codes of conduct, save for organised duels. They tend toward lawful and neutral alignments

entries.name: Size
entries: Aldani are around 8 feet long, rising to a height of 5 feet or so. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 20 feet, and you have a swimming speed of 30 feet.

entries.name: Amphibious
entries: You can breathe air and water.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Claws
entries: Your enormous pincers are natural weapons, which you can use to make unarmed strikes. If you hit with them, you deal slashing damage equal to {@dice 1d8} + your Strength modifier.

A target hit by your claw attack is {@condition grappled}. You have two claws, each of which can grapple only one target. The escape DC for this grapple is 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier.

entries.name: Underwater Adaption
entries: You ignore any drawbacks caused by an underwater environment.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common.

The aldani, or lobsterfolk, are a rare sight in the Forgotten Realms. These creatures resemble giant lobsters that walk upright and have humanoid faces save for the chitinous armour that clads them, and their eyestalks. Aldani vary in colour, red Aldani are common in Chult, and blue in the Trackless Sea.

Aldani are peaceful yet xenophobic. The aldani of Chult live almost exclusively in the Aldani Basin, where they stay in seclusion from the surrounding sentient races. The lobsterfolk of the Trackless Sea are often found in monasteries in the pursuit of inner peace

entries.name: Aldani Names
entries: Aldani take names similar to the local humans. Their primary language is Common, thus taking human names is easy for them. Despite this, lobsterfolk can communicate through a second language, a series of clacks and snaps produced by their pincers. An individual aldani might have a series of sounds it uses instead. Aldani care little for family lines, nor do they make any distinction between genders or sexes, thus all aldani use a single, unisex name.

These piscine, shark-like humanoids are best known as bloodthirsty raiders who decimate coastal villages and devour the populace. Sahuagin are prone to mutation, and their leaders grow extra sets of arms and grow twice as large as their kin. Other morphs include venomous sacks, and even the external appearance of a sea elf. Because of this latter mutation, sahuagin have an ongoing enmity with the sea elves. Although most sahuagin are brutal half-beats devoted to evil, there are some that break the norm.

entries.name: Sahuagin Names
entries: Though most sahuagin communicate in their own snarling language, their names can be rendered in the Common tongue. Sahuagin first names are defined by gender, as their society has defined gender roles, and their second name pertains to the tribe to which they belong.

items.name: Female Names:
items.entry: Attakl, Chorg, Favakl, Khorg, Vathakl

items.name: Male Names:
items.entry: Dhurge, Gharg, Khoth, Sittl, Zathl

items.name: Tribe Names:
items.entry: Bloodbather, Coastraider, Gutfeaster, Sharkbreeder, Spawn of Sekolah

table.name: Madness of Slakrethel
colLabels: Flaw (lasts until cured by a {@spell wish} spell)
rows: "Пьянство помогает мне быть в здравом уме".
"Я украшаю себя рыбьими скелетами, моюсь в морской воде и ношу одежду из матовых водорослей".
"Со мной связался Сларкретель, который говорит со мной через мои сны".
"Я убежден, что должен погружаться в соленую воду каждые восемь часов, иначе я умру".
"Победить Сларкретела - моя единственная цель. Ничто не встанет между мной и моей целью".
"Я ем только сырую рыбу и морские водоросли".
"Я постоянно ковыряюсь в своей коже, пытаясь найти чешуйки и присоски, которые, как я знаю, находятся под ней".
"Океан пугает меня; нахождение на побережье вызывает у меня дрожь, а погружение под воду убьет меня".
"Я убежден, что Общество Кракена охотится за мной, и их агенты постоянно наблюдают за мной".
"Я вижу сжимающиеся щупальца в тенях. Это ужасы глубин, которые хотят поглотить меня".
"Я ничего не могу воспринимать всерьез. Чем серьезнее ситуация, тем смешнее она мне кажется".
"Человеческие жертвы - единственный способ умиротворить кракена, Сларкретель".

table.name: Brawl Mishaps
table.caption: Brawl Mishaps
rows: Из соседней комнаты вбегает {@creature thug|MM} и обрушивает корабельный штурвал на голову персонажа, нанося 11 ({@damage 2d10}) урона от удара.

Шальной флаг пролетает по воздуху и попадает в Одноглазого Билла {@creature wereshark|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}), который превращается в гибрид человека и акулы и нападает на того, кто ближе всех.
Громадный {@creature Half-Ogre (Ogrillon)|mm|half-ogre} пират врезается в одну из стен таверны, заставляя пару разбойников полностью расступиться. Затем драка выплескивается на улицу.

Одна из ламп, освещающих таверну, разбивается, и горящее масло проливается на блюдо с напитками, вызывая сильный пожар в квадрате 10 футов. Существо в огне получает 11 ({@damage 2d10}) повреждений от огня и воспламеняется, получая 3 ({@damage 1d6}) повреждений от огня в начале каждого своего хода. Огонь может быть ликвидирован действием и распространяется по усмотрению DM.

Прогнившее основание главной мачты подается, когда на нее бросается бандит, и проскальзывает в комнату через потолок. Каждое существо в линии шириной 5 футов и длиной 30 футов должно сделать бросок на спасбросок ловкости DC 12 или получить 16 ({@damage 3d10}) повреждений от удара.

Кто-то бросает в толпу дымовую шашку, которая взрывается в радиусе десяти футов, нанося 2 ({@damage 1d4}) урона силы всем, кто находится поблизости. Затем пространство заполняется густым черным дымом, сильно заслоняя 15-футовую сферу таверны.

footnotes.name: Aldani
entries: The characters are shadowed by {@dice 1d4} {@creature aldani (lobsterfolk)|Toa|aldani} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}), which are noticed by any character with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 12 or higher. The aldani don't communicate with others unless they must, and they won't fight unless the characters refuse to take a bribe to leave the area. The aldani aid the characters only if they're offered something of great value in return–for example, an offer to drive off a pack of predatory sahuagin encroaching on their territory.

footnotes.name: Coelenites
entries: The characters are attacked by {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) who try and pull them down into the water and drown them. The {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} try to avoid leaving the ocean if possible but foray onto the shore or climb aboard boats to pursue their prey.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are 4th level or higher, replace one of the {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} with a {@creature coelenite mass mind|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). The {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} telepathically threaten the characters with drowning unless they provide a tribute of food. The {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} can be appeased with food (four day's supply per coelenite in the group). Otherwise, they attack.

footnotes.name: Dolphins
entries: The characters spot a pod of {@dice 3d4} {@creature dolphin|vgm|dolphins} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). If the characters are above the surface of the water, they notice the beautiful creatures leaping between the waves. They are naturally inquisitive and might come within 10 feet of the boat to take a look.

A {@creature dolphin|vgm} that is successfully {@condition grappled}, caught in a {@item net|phb}, or otherwise prevented from escaping can be trained as a mount by a character with proficiency in {@skill Animal Handling} who spends a few hours a day working with the mammal. At the end of 1 week, the character makes a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check. On a success, the dolphin becomes a willing mount for any humanoid.

footnotes.name: Floating Debris
entries: The characters notice something floating one hundred feet away. A successful DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check reveals the nature of the debris. Roll a {@dice d6}:

items.name: 1–3.
entries: Barrels and crates.

items.name: 4–5.
entries: Shattered wooden planks.
Chests.

entries.name: Barrels and Crates
entries: Bobbing on the waves are {@dice 4d4} crates and {@item barrel|phb|barrels} filled with goods. These may contain alcohol, {@item rations (1 day)|phb|rations}, rope or other basic items typically found aboard ships.

entries.name: Shattered Wooden Planks
entries: Planks of shattered wood float atop the ocean. Clearly, these are remnants of a ship which has been recently attacked and perhaps destroyed. There is a {@chance 50} chance that a pirate ship is nearby (see "Pirate Ship" in this section).

entries.name: Chests
entries: Mostly sunk beneath the water's surface are {@dice 1d4} {@item chest|phb|chests}. These must have been jettisoned from another vessel. The {@item chest|phb|chests} are locked and keyless and require a successful DC 14 Dexterity check with {@item thieves' tools|phb} or a successful DC 16 Strength check to open. Inside are valuable items worth 100 gp, such as money, gems, candlesticks, jewellery and the like. There is a {@chance 10} chance that the chest contains a more expensive item worth 250 gp, such as a gemstone or {@table 250 gp art objects|dmg|art object}. This could be replaced with a magic item (roll once on {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

footnotes.name: Giant Crab
entries: A {@creature giant crab} scuttles out from a kelp forest or coastal cave and attacks a random character. The target is surprised unless they have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 14 or higher. The crab attempts to {@action grapple} the character, then drop overboard with them and drown them (see "{@book Suffocating|phb|8|Suffocating|0}" in chapter 8 of the {@i Player's Handbook}). If the encounter occurs at sea, the crab claws its way up the hull to ambush the character.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are above 4th level, consider using a {@creature hulking crab|SKT} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}).

footnotes.name: Giant Lightning Eel
entries: A {@creature giant lightning eel|tftyp} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) shoots out from a coral reef or rocky crevasse to attack a random character. The character targeted by the eel is surprised unless they have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 13 or higher.

footnotes.name: Giant Octopus
entries: A {@creature giant octopus} shows some curiosity in the characters. The intelligent animal uses its dextrous tentacles to search their backpacks for food or curious treasures that it can steal away to its hoard. So long as the characters don't attack it, the octopus is not hostile. If the octopus finds a {@item rations (1 day)|phb|ration} or shiny treasure on the characters, it attempts to steal it. The octopus makes a Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check against the characters passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}). If the octopus succeeds, it steals the item and swims back to its lair.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are above 5th level, consider using a colossal octopus ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}).

footnotes.name: Giant Sea Horses
entries: The characters encounter {@dice 1d4} friendly {@creature giant sea horse|mm|giant sea horses}. Like their smaller kin, giant sea horses are shy, colourful fish with elongated bodies and curled tails. These creatures are often trained as mounts by aquatic elves.

A giant sea horse that is {@condition grappled}, caught in a {@item net|phb}, or otherwise prevented from escaping can be trained as a mount by a character with proficiency in {@skill Animal Handling}. At the end of 1 week with the animal, the character makes a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check. On a success, the giant sea horse becomes a willing mount for any humanoid.

footnotes.name: Giant Shark
entries: A {@creature giant shark} surges through the water toward the party and attacks a random character. The size of the creature makes it impossible to miss, and the characters each have a turn to try and flee or {@action hide} before it arrives and attacks. Giant sharks are 30 feet long and utterly fearless.

entries.name: Ships
entries: If this encounter occurs while the characters are on a ship, the giant shark attacks whatever vessel the characters are on. These enormous fish are capable of sinking smaller ships but are just as likely to ram larger ones to try and knock unsuspecting crew overboard. If the shark rams the ship, and characters on deck must make a DC 16 Dexterity saving throw or be thrown overboard.

footnotes.name: Giant Spider
entries: The characters are ambushed by a {@creature giant spider}.

entries.name: Sea
entries: Whilst travelling through an area of low visibility, such as a rocky crevasse or a coral reef, a random character is attacked by a {@creature giant spider} with a swim speed of 30 ft. The character is surprised unless they have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 17 or higher.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: If the characters succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check, they can track back to the spider's lair; a sheltered cave covered in sticky webs with corpses hanging from the ceiling. There is a {@chance 25} chance that one of these corpses has a magic item, determined by rolling on {@table Magic Item Table B} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

footnotes.name: Kelpie
entries: A hypnotic {@creature kelpie|tftyp} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}), an intelligent, aquatic plant that resembles a pile of seaweed, tries to lure one of the characters to their death. The {@creature kelpie|tftyp} can take the form of a {@filter Small, Medium or Large beast or humanoid|bestiary|size=S;M;L|type=beast;humanoid}, and uses this to its advantage, posing as a desirable creature such as a giant sea horse, or a stranded commoner drowning in rough seas.

footnotes.name: Killer Whales
entries: The party is attacked by a pod of {@dice 1d4 + 2} {@creature killer whale|mm|killer whales} who surge toward them through the water. If the characters are on a vessel that couldn't be capsized by the orcas, they simply notice them hunting not far from the ship.

footnotes.name: Kraken Sighting
entries: A huge shadow passes beneath the vessel on which the party sail. A successful DC 16 Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) or Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check allows characters to realise that the form is a {@creature kraken}. It pays no attention to the ship unless attacked by the crew.
Obviously, any crew members who notice the beast are be terrified, fleeing into the belly of the ship, muttering prayers or climbing up rigging.

If you wish, the kraken could be {@creature Slarkrethel|SKT} (see {@adventure chapter 5|CallfromtheDeep|9} for his full statistics). This gives the characters the chance to realise that not all is well with the kraken, thanks to the exposed brain, which is actually Zellix'Phor the {@creature elder brain|vgm}.

footnotes.name: Lycanthropes
entries: Depending on where the characters are exploring, they come across one or more lycanthropes. The lycanthropes might be initially encountered in their animal, hybrid, or humanoid form depending on the focus of the encounter.

entries.name: Coast, Sea & Underwater
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature wereshark|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) hunting during the day or camping at night. Weresharks are loners and tend to be rude or hostile. If a {@creature wereshark|CallfromtheDeep} gets a taste for humanoid flesh, it takes great mental fortitude to oppress the urge to kill.

footnotes.name: Mephits
entries: The characters might encounter {@creature dust mephit|mm|dust mephits}, {@creature ice mephit|mm|ice mephits}, {@creature mud mephit|mm|mud mephits}, or {@creature steam mephit|mm|steam mephits} (each appearing as a group of {@dice 2d6}). The mephits don't attack unless they outnumber the characters two to one, but they're reluctant to be helpful unless they themselves are outnumbered.

footnotes.name: Merfolk
entries: Emerging from the depths are a group of {@dice 2d6 + 2} {@creature merfolk} traders. These peaceful, water-dwelling folk come to the surface in order to trade with passing ships. They don't value gold but instead delight in useful magical items or metal weapons that they lack the ability to craft. In return, they can offer treasures of the deep such as {@item pearl|dmg|pearls}, necklaces, and armour made of corals, glowing jellyfish in glass jars and magic potions. They may also have strange artifacts that they have scavenged from the depths such as parts of the crash-landed Illithid ship. Crew members often become infatuated with {@creature merfolk} and go on about them for days after the encounter.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The merfolk group carry treasures worth 250 gp. There is a {@chance 50} chance that they carry {@dice 1d4} magic items, determined by rolling on {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

footnotes.name: Merrow
entries: The characters encounter {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature merrow} in the depths. They hunt humanoids in fishing vessels or on the coast. Their main tactic is to harpoon creatures into the water and drown them, taking their corpses down to underwater grottoes to feed. There is a {@chance 25} chance that the merrow have {@dice 1d4} {@creature merfolk} prisoners with them, bound in thick kelp rope. The {@creature merfolk} are from a nearby settlement where the characters could take refuge should they choose to free the prisoners.

footnotes.name: Nereid
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature nereid|tftyp} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}); a fey creature of otherworldly beauty. There is a {@chance 50} chance that the neried is good aligned and can help guide the characters through the next leg of their journey or point them in the direction of a previously unknown location. An evil aligned nereid convinces the characters into believing that they are good before using their drowning kiss and aquatic invisibility to launch a deadly surprise attack.

footnotes.name: Ruins
entries: The adventurers come across a small ruin; the remains of a wizard tower, a dilapidated dwarven mine, an abandoned goblinoid fort, a destroyed aquatic elf city beneath the waves, or a sunken ship. If the characters camp here, and the ruins are not already occupied (see below), they can finish a long rest with no chance of an encounter.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: There is a {@chance 50} chance the ruins are inhabited; {@creature sahuagin baron} on the coast, {@dice 1d4 - 1} {@creature owlbear|mm|owlbears} in the forest, {@dice 2d4} of {@creature centaur} in grasslands, an {@creature ettin} in hills or moors, a {@creature nothic} by the roadside, or {@dice 1d4 - 1} {@creature sea lion|tftyp|sea lions} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) underwater.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: If the ruins are home to a creature, there is treasure within. If not, there is still a {@chance 50} chance that the ruins contain treasure. Roll a {@dice d20}:

items.name: 1–10.
items.entry: A humanoid skeleton clad in rusted armour holding a {@item silvered weapon|phb|silvered, nonmagical weapon} (your choice) with {@dice 1d4} magic items in a mouldy satchel (roll on {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

items.name: 11–15.
items.entry: A humanoid corpse clutching a weapon (your choice) and a pouch containing {@dice 3d4} 50 gp gems.

items.name: 15–17.
items.entry: A smashed {@item chest|phb} containing a dozen battered books, {@dice 1d4} {@item trinket|phb|trinkets} (see chapter 5, "{@book Equipment|phb|6|Trinkets}" of the {@i Player's Handbook}) and {@dice 1d4} magic items (roll on {@table Magic Item Table B} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

items.name: 18–19.
items.entry: A monster hoard containing {@dice 2d6} 50 gp gems and {@dice 1d4} magic items (roll on {@table Magic Item Table C} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).
A slain adventurer atop a monster hoard containing {@dice 3d4} 50 gp gems and {@dice 1d4} magic items (roll on {@table Magic Item Table D} in chapter 7 on the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

footnotes.name: Sahuagin
entries: The party encounter a gang of {@dice 2d4 + 2} {@creature sahuagin} accompanied by {@dice 1d4 + 2} {@creature hunter shark|mm|hunter sharks}. There is a {@chance 20} chance that the hunting party is led by a {@creature sahuagin priestess} or a {@creature sahuagin raider|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). The {@creature sahuagin} attempt to throw characters into the water where the {@creature hunter shark|mm|sharks} viciously maul them. {@creature Sahuagin} have a hatred for elves, and always attack elven characters first if possible.

The sea devils have been stirred up by the influence of Zellix'Phor. Previously, the {@creature sahuagin} had little to do with Slarkrethel but since the discovery of the nautiloid crash, things have changed. Pieces of strange mind flayer technology have made their way into the hands of the {@creature sahuagin}, who have distributed it throughout their tribes, spreading the influence of the elder brain. The sea devils may carry with them {@item spear|phb|spears} made of strange metal, foreign tablets with {@language Qualith|vgm} inscriptions, or even weapons created by the illithid for them (see {@book Volo's Guide to Monsters|vgm|0|Mind Flayers: Scourge of Worlds}).
{@creature Sahuagin} carry exotic weapons adorned with pearls, coral and other naturally beautiful items. Each weapon is worth twice its normal value.
entries.name: Treasure

footnotes.name: Salty Sea Dogs
entries: Whilst travelling the high seas, the party encounter an NPC (or group thereof) who provide the chance for roleplay, gaining allies, making enemies, or gathering information:

entries.name: Flotsam & Jetsam
entries: (CN male and female {@creature goblin|mm|goblins}) This pair of {@creature goblin|mm|goblins} have fashioned themselves a barely seaworthy vessel from an old {@item barrel|phb}, using a tablecloth for a sail. They both have the additional skill: {@skill Sleight of Hand} {@dice 1d20+6|+6} and are kleptomaniacs. The {@creature goblin|mm|goblins} can become steadfast allies, who happily accompany the crew rather than remain in their dangerous little boat. They are also willing to "... swashbuckle..." alongside the characters but might not be able to resist pinching a particularly shiny piece of treasure from them should the opportunity arise.

entries.name: Anka
entries: (NN female {@creature anka|CallfromtheDeep|ogre} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12})). Previously the first mate of the notorious Captain Callous, {@creature Anka|CallfromtheDeep} made her last dim-witted mistake upon 'The Devil's Fin' and was forced to walk the plank by the captain. The characters encounter her 'starfished' on her back in the water, desperately trying to stay afloat. {@creature Anka|CallfromtheDeep|Anka's} left arm has been replaced with a huge anchor which is slowly dragging her down. If saved, {@creature Anka|CallfromtheDeep} temporarily allies with the characters, helping them track Captain Callous. Despite this, a successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check by Captain Callous causes her to come back to his side.

entries.name: T'zen'lix
entries: (LE male {@creature neogi|vgm}). T'zen'lix is an alien, spiderlike creature from the Astral Plane that accidently ended up here after stowing away on the nautiloid. When it crashlanded, 'Lix managed to enslave a farmer from Gundarlun and escape. Since then, 'Lix has been on a whirlwind ride discovering that wanton control over living beings often ends in sticky situations. 'Lix mostly wants to get back to the Astral Plane and joins together with the characters if they can help him achieve this goal. 'Lix doesn't think twice about mind controlling the characters to alleviate even the smallest of stresses for himself.

entries.name: Mei Ling
entries: (LE female {@creature vampire} with a swim speed of 30 ft.) Mei Ling is a vampire who lives in the underwater ruins of Narino, north of Mintarn. Normally Mei Ling feeds on the blood of merfolk and sea elves, but from time to time she rises from her underwater lair to sample Tarnian blood and make mischief. She might clamber aboard the ship and drain the blood of a Tarnian crew member, try to sabotage the vessel, or turn the cabin boy into a {@creature vampire spawn}. Mei Ling doesn't consider the ocean to be running water. For more information about Mei Ling and Narino, see "{@adventure Open Lord Dagult Neverember's Quest|CallfromtheDeep|3|Dagult Neverember's Quest|0}" in {@adventure chapter 2|CallfromtheDeep|3}.

entries.name: Toroa
entries: (CN female Chultan human {@creature war priest|vgm} of Kahulla) Hailing from a far-flung island nation south of the Sword Coast, Toroa belongs to The Chosen of the Stormheart, an order of clerics sent out into the world to chase down the largest storms and commune with their patron goddess Kahulla, an aspect of {@deity Talos|Faerûnian|scag}. Toroa is hot on the tail of an enormous tempest that is, unbeknownst to her, a {@creature storm giant quintessent|vgm}. Torora has dusky skin, electric blue hair and a preference for lightning magic.

footnotes.name: Sea Hags
entries: The characters encounter three {@creature sea hag|mm|sea hags} that comprise a coven. Their favourite trick is to pretend to be stranded or wounded peasants in need of rescue in a damaged or beached rowboat.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: If the characters defeat the {@creature sea hag|mm|sea hags} and search the area, roll twice on {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} to determine what they find. Whatever treasure the hags have is stowed inside a rotted wooden {@item chest|phb}.

footnotes.name: Sea Lions
entries: The characters encounter {@dice 1d3} {@creature sea lion|tftyp|sea lions} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}); fearsome monsters with the head and forepaws of a lion and the lower body and tail of a fish. If this encounter occurs during the day, they are hunting a group of {@creature dolphin|vgm|dolphins} or a whale. If the encounter occurs at night, they are guarding their lair which contains {@dice 2d4} {@creature sea cub|CallfromtheDeep|sea cubs} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). {@creature sea cub|CallfromtheDeep|Sea cubs} are a prized pet among fishing communities and can be sold for 50 gp.

footnotes.name: Sea Spawn
entries: The characters come across {@dice 3d4 + 2} {@creature sea spawn|CallfromtheDeep}. These disturbing, piscine humanoids are the creation of Slarkrethel the kraken. There is a {@chance 25} chance that these {@creature sea spawn|CallfromtheDeep} have prisoners in tow. A sample group of prisoners is presented here, but you can create others.

The prisoners are {@dice 1d4 + 1} Northlander human {@creature commoner|mm|commoners} from Uttersea on Tuern. The strongest among them is a young woman named Nadya Greenrock. The {@creature sea spawn|CallfromtheDeep} raided the town of Uttersea during the night, slipping past the guards thanks to their humanoid forms. They slipped into the houses of the local folk and kidnapped them from their beds. The {@creature sea spawn|CallfromtheDeep} are taking the prisoners to Ascarle to be consumed by the Illithid colony. The prisoners can survive underwater thanks to the {@spell water breathing} spell cast by one of the {@creature sea spawn|CallfromtheDeep}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The {@creature sea spawn|CallfromtheDeep} have {@dice 1d3 - 1} {@item spell scroll (3rd level)|dmg|spell scrolls} of {@spell water breathing} among them. If the characters can rescue the Tuernish villagers and escort them back to Uttersea, they are rewarded by High King Ossul Haarn with a {@item longship|CallfromtheDeep} named 'Flamescale'.

footnotes.name: Sharks
entries: The characters are attacked by either {@dice 1d3} {@creature hunter shark|mm|hunter sharks} or {@dice 2d4} {@creature reef shark|mm|reef sharks} depending on what variety of location they are in. Characters in large ships that could not be capsized by the sharks can easily avoid this encounter, so consider having it occur at a later date when a character or crew member has fallen overboard.

footnotes.name: Storm Giant
entries: Looming up ahead of the characters, either rising from the water, sailing in an enormous dinghy or lumbering along the sea floor is a lone {@creature storm giant}. {@creature Storm giant|mm|Storm giants} are typically good aligned and willing to help the characters if they explain their situation. A successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check is enough to convince a giant to fight with the party during their next combat. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, the giant can escort the characters to Maelstrom (see "Maelstrom" in chapter 3).

footnotes.name: Treant
entries: The characters hear a crashing from the forest and spot a {@creature treant} from a safe distance away. The {@creature treant} has been awoken by a shift in the natural balance and is confused by the changing cycle. There is a {@chance 50} chance that the {@creature treant} is curious and friendly, or confused and angry.

entries.name: Underwater
entries: The {@creature treant} resembles a giant anemone.

entries.name: Repeat Encounters
entries: Instead of a {@creature treant}, you can replace this encounter with a {@creature shambling mound} that stealthily makes its way toward camped characters, or lies in wait beside a trail for them to draw near. When encountered underwater, a {@creature shambling mound} resembles a coralencrusted heap covered in seaweed.

footnotes.name: Trolls
entries: The characters are ambushed by {@dice 1d2} {@creature troll|mm|trolls}. They attack from behind ridges, thickets, and even kelp forests. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 11 or higher notice the {@creature troll|mm|trolls} from a safe distance and can attempt to flee, otherwise the characters are surprised.

entries.name: Sea & Underwater
entries: Saltwater trolls are called {@creature scrag|CallfromtheDeep|scrags}. They use the {@creature troll} stat block with the following changes:

items: Скорость плавания скрагов составляет 30 футов.

items.name: Amphibious
entries: Скраг может дышать воздухом и водой.

items.name: Aquatic Regeneration
entries: The scrag regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it fully submerged in water. If the scrag takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the scrag's next turn. The scrag only dies if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

footnotes.name: Vodyanoi
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature vodyanoi|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) which attacks a random character or their ship. These relatives of the {@creature umber hulk} are capable of punching through ship hulls or capsizing smaller vessels.

footnotes.name: Whirlpool
entries: The roar of the waves increases and spray shoots into the air. A whirlpool forms {@dice 1d4 × 10} feet away from characters or their ship, the pull of which can immediately be felt.

The whirlpool forms a vortex that is 5 feet wide at the base, 50 feet wide at the top, and 25 feet tall. Any creature or object in the water and within 25 feet of the vortex is pulled 10 feet toward it. A creature can swim away from the vortex with a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. A ship can be rowed away if the crew succeed on a the same group check.

A creature or object that enters the vortex for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must make a DC 15 Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 2d8} bludgeoning damage and is caught in the vortex. On a successful save, the creature takes half damage and isn't caught. A creature caught in the vortex can use its action to try to escape from the vortex as described above but has disadvantage on the Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check to do so. A ship's crew can attempt the same group check.
A creature pulled beneath the waves must hold its breath or begin to drown (see chapter 8 of the {@i Player's Handbook|phb} for rules on "{@book Suffocating|phb|8|Suffocating|0}").

footnotes.name: Ankheg
entries: A group of {@dice 1d3} {@creature ankheg|mm|ankhegs} bursts up from beneath the ground to ambush the characters. Any character without {@sense tremorsense|MM} is surprised by the attack. Ankhegs prefer Small creatures, which they grab with their mandibles and drag back underground to consume.

footnotes.name: Bandits
entries: A marauding gang of bandits confronts the party. The gang consists of a {@creature bandit captain} and {@dice 3d6 + 2} {@creature bandit|mm|bandits}, all wearing cloaks and mounted on {@creature riding horse|mm|riding horses}. There is a {@chance 25} chance that the bandits attack without provocation. Otherwise, the captain promises not to attack in exchange for a toll (no less than 100 gp worth of treasure). If the characters pay up, the captain bids them a safe journey before departing peacefully.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each bandit carries a pouch containing {@dice 1d10} gp. The bandit captain's pouch holds {@dice 2d10} gp and {@dice 1d6} gems worth 100 gp each.

footnotes.name: Blood Hawks
entries: A vicious kettle of {@dice 2d4+2} {@creature blood hawk|mm|blood hawks} attacks the party from above. These crimson raptors are fearless and attack large creatures without second thought. The hawks target already injured characters or those who look weaker than the rest of the party.

footnotes.name: Goblinoids
entries: A typical goblin patrol or hunting party consists of a {@creature goblin boss} leading {@dice 2d6 + 3} {@creature goblin|mm|goblins}. Goblins tend to have their own territories which they seldom leave. Goblins prefer to hunt at night and lay low in ambush positions during the day.

A night encounter with goblins involves an attack on the characters' camp. A character standing watch with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 16 or higher detects the goblins moving into attack positions and can rouse the rest of the party. If no one on watch notices the goblins, all characters are surprised.

If this encounter occurs while the characters are traveling during the day, any characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 16 or higher spots the tell-tale signs of an ambush: disadvantageous terrain coupled with an eerie silence not normal for the environment.

Goblins bargain for their lives if captured. If the characters can force or coerce a vow of cooperation from goblin prisoners, they will serve as guides. Goblins in their home territory have the following additional skill: {@skill Survival} {@dice 1d20+1|+1}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The gang of goblins have amassed 50 gp of assorted goods from ambushing travellers.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are above 4th level, there is a {@chance 50} chance that the goblins are led by {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature bugbear|mm|bugbears} and the {@creature goblin boss} is replaced by a {@creature bugbear chief}. When under the command of bugbears, goblins do not flee unless all the bugbears are killed.

footnotes.name: Hill Giants
entries: A band of {@dice 1d3} {@creature hill giant|mm|hill giants} is searching for homesteads to pillage or bands of travellers to capture. The giants hurl rocks at any small folk they see. {@creature Hill giant|mm|Hill giants} are dim creatures and are easily tricked by misdirection and illusions. Characters might even be able to slip past a group of them while they argue with each other about who has the biggest belly, or whose feet smell the worst.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The giants carry a sack with them which contains a bundle of mundane items such as wagon wheels, tombstones, beehives and casks of ale. There is {@chance 25} chance that the bag also contains Garrin Brandybrush (NG male Stout halfling {@creature commoner} with 0 hit points), three cats stolen by accident from a nearby farm, or one {@creature boar} to which the giants have tied half a dozen humanoid skulls.

footnotes.name: Knight
entries: The Order of the Gauntlet is taking strides to deal with the pirate threat. The characters encounter a {@creature knight} of the order mounted on a {@creature warhorse} clad in {@item chain mail|phb} {@item barding|phb} (AC 16). There is a {@chance 50} chance that the {@creature knight} has a squire–a {@creature guard} mounted on an unarmoured {@creature warhorse}. Two sample knights are presented below.

Marcheon Amander Chilcott (LG non-binary Illuskan human {@creature knight} of {@deity Tyr|Faerûnian|scag}) is a gallant yet ferocious Knight of the Merciful Sword who prefers to reform rather than destroy criminals. Chilcott and her squire recently raided a smuggler's cove filled with pirates and captured their leader, Captain Uthak 'Nightbringer' Katho-Olavi (NE male goliath {@creature berserker}). Nightbringer is an immensely tall goliath, covered in wave tattoos and bound with three pairs of {@item manacles|phb}. Marcheon Chilcott asks the characters to escort the captain to the nearest settlement while she heads back to the cove to ensure it is securely boarded up.

Lady Luciette Falconcrown (NG female Chondathan human {@creature knight} of {@deity Helm|Faerûnian|scag}) is a member of the Order of the Gilded Eye from Helm's Hold. Lady Falconcrown believes that evil should be actively sought out and punished before it has a chance to rear its ugly head. She wears a golden gauntlet emblazoned with a weeping eye on her right hand which marks her allegiance. Lady Falconcrown is currently searching for Zhentarim agents who she believes should be held accountable for their faction's misdemeanours. She asks the characters to give up anyone they know who is affiliated with the Black Network and tells them to take her to the traitors, so she can personally deliver them to justice.

footnotes.name: Kraken Society Cultists
entries: The characters encounter a sullen group of {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature spy|mm|spies} or {@creature cultist|mm|cultists} wearing grey hooded cloaks, led by a {@creature cult fanatic} wearing a purple robe over a {@item breastplate|phb} (AC 16) embossed with a kraken design. These minor agents of the society are on a mission to gather information about merchant movements, explore unmapped coastline, sabotage Lord's Alliance ships or hire pirate crews. These low-ranking members of the cult have no idea that they are genuinely working for a kraken, and certainly have no idea that said kraken has been dominated by an elder brain.

A character can determine that the cultists are members of the Kraken Society with a successful DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check. The cultists pass by unless they are attacked, in which case they retaliate with lethal force. Only the {@creature cult fanatic} leader knows what their specific mission is, and if the characters question them, Zellix'Phor can use an action on its turn to telepathically deal 40 psychic damage to them, enough to kill them instantly.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each cultist carries a pouch containing {@dice 1d10} gp. The leader's ornamented {@item breastplate|phb} is worth 450 gp, and they carry a pouch containing {@dice 2d10} gp and {@dice 1d4} gems worth 50 gp each. At the DM's discretion, the cultists could be carrying correspondence or maps pertaining to the characters' quests to help get them moving in the right direction.

footnotes.name: Lycanthropes
entries: Depending on where the characters are exploring, they come across one or more lycanthropes. The lycanthropes might be initially encountered in their animal, hybrid, or humanoid form depending on the focus of the encounter.

entries.name: Road/Trail
entries: A pack of {@dice 2d4 + 2} {@creature wererat|mm|wererats} is migrating from one town to the next. These folk are often moved on from city to city when their nocturnal activities become evident. {@creature wererat|mm|Wererats} are always on the look out for new recruits. The {@creature wererat|mm|wererats} have 200 gp of stolen art objects.

entries.name: On Land
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature draft horse} pulling a {@item wagon|phb}. Accompanying the {@item wagon|phb} are {@dice 1d6 - 1} people (use the {@creature commoner} stat block unless otherwise noted below). If the die result indicates that no one is present, it means the drivers are either missing or dead, leaving the horse and {@item wagon|phb} unattended. If one or more people are present, assume that they are guiding the {@item wagon|phb} toward the nearest settlement. The encounter might be one of the following:

items: Friendly furriers transporting {@dice 2d4} bundles of animal pelts worth 50 gp per bundle.
Friendly peddlers transporting {@dice 3d6} ten-gallon kegs of dwarven ale worth 5 gp each.
Friendly, dirt-poor musicians looking for a tavern; the wagon holds their instruments and gear.
Hostile {@creature bandit|mm|bandits} (NE Illuskan humans) posing as friendly traders, transporting a stolen wagon laden with foodstuffs to their encampment.
A family fleeing their coastal village in the wake of rumours of pirate attacks; the wagon contains their food and their mundane belongings.

A friendly merchant transporting {@dice 2d4} {@creature pig|skt|pigs} worth 3 gp each; any other persons present are Zhentarim {@creature guard|mm|guards} (N humans of various ethnicities) hired to ward off bandits.

Friendly Zhentarim mercenaries (NG human {@creature veteran|mm|veterans} of various ethnicities) transporting thirty {@item longsword|phb|longswords} (worth 15 gp each) and fifty {@item shortsword|phb|shortswords} (worth 10 gp each) to a Zhent merchant waiting for them in the nearest settlement.

footnotes.name: Ogres
entries: The characters hear loud, deep voices and spot {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature ogre|mm|ogres} from a safe distance away. The big dummies are lost and trying to find their way home. The characters catch them in the middle of a loud argument about which direction they should go and can easily avoid the {@creature ogre|mm|ogres} or take them by surprise.

footnotes.name: Orcs
entries: The characters come across {@dice 3d6 + 2} {@creature orc|mm|orcs}. There is a {@chance 25} chance that these orcs have prisoners in tow. A sample group of prisoners is presented here, but you can create others.

The prisoners are {@dice 1d4 + 2} rock gnome {@creature commoner|mm|commoners} belonging to the Frackle clan. The oldest among them is a barmy old tinker named Nissanab 'Fizzlebang' Frackle. The {@creature orc|mm|orcs} smoked out the Frackle burrow and captured these family members as they tried to flee. The prisoners are smoke-stained and coughing. The Frackles have managed to create rudimentary firearms, including a {@item pistol} which the lead {@creature orc} has stolen, though he only has 5 bullets. Fizzlebang has a pouch of 25 additional bullets. For more information on firearms and explosives, see chapter 9, "{@book Dungeon Master's Workshop|dmg|9|Firearms|0}," of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: If the characters escort the Frackles back to their burrow, the gnomes are reunited with the members of their family who avoided capture. One of them rewards the party with a family heirloom (a magic item) hidden in the burnt remains of the family home. Roll on {@table Magic Item Table F} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} to determine the item.

footnotes.name: Ranger
entries: The characters encounter a helpful ranger; a member of the Emerald Enclave or simply a wilderness wanderer. The ranger is happy to serve as a guide or source of information. There is a {@chance 50} chance that the ranger has a {@creature riding horse}, one or more beast companions, or both. A ranger with neither travels alone on foot. Two sample rangers are presented below, but you can create others:

Berri (CG female firbolg {@creature scout}) can cast {@spell detect magic} and {@spell disguise self}. She only appears to characters that are lost or in desperate need. She initially appears as an elf to avoid revealing her true identity, but if the characters are kind, she reveals her true form. Berri always carries dried fruit in small cloth parcels which she might leave for desperate adventurers. She also makes sure to carry a bundle of vials filled with an invigorating alcoholic draft which puts a drinker under the effects of a {@spell bless} spell for 1 hour.

Throkk Ampleford (CN male half-orc {@creature archer|vgm} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12})) is an incredible game hunter who has been living on The High Moor for the past decade. He was born in Neverwinter, but outcast because of his orcish heritage. Throkk has a pet {@creature hawk} named Streak who's catches rabbits and squirrels. Throkk has the additional skill: {@skill Survival} {@dice 1d20+5|+5}. He can use his knowledge of the local area to help characters hunt. Throkk also loves to fletch and crafts arrows for the characters as a gift before they part ways.

footnotes.name: Ruins
entries: The adventurers come across a small ruin; the remains of a wizard tower, a dilapidated dwarven mine, an abandoned goblinoid fort, a destroyed aquatic elf city beneath the waves, or a sunken ship. If the characters camp here, and the ruins are not already occupied (see below), they can finish a long rest with no chance of an encounter.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: There is a {@chance 50} chance the ruins are inhabited; {@creature sahuagin baron} on the coast, {@dice 1d4 - 1} {@creature owlbear|mm|owlbears} in the forest, {@dice 2d4} of {@creature centaur} in grasslands, an {@creature ettin} in hills or moors, a {@creature nothic} by the roadside, or {@dice 1d4 - 1} {@creature sea lion|tftyp|sea lions} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) underwater.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: If the ruins are home to a creature, there is treasure within. If not, there is still a {@chance 50} chance that the ruins contain treasure. Roll a {@dice d20}:

items.name: 1–10.
items.entry: A humanoid skeleton clad in rusted armour holding a {@item silvered weapon|phb|silvered, nonmagical weapon} (your choice) with {@dice 1d4} magic items in a mouldy satchel (roll on {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

items.name: 11–15.
items.entry: A humanoid corpse clutching a weapon (your choice) and a pouch containing {@dice 3d4} 50 gp gems.

items.name: 15–17.
items.entry: A smashed {@item chest|phb} containing a dozen battered books, {@dice 1d4} {@item trinket|phb|trinkets} (see chapter 5, "{@book Equipment|phb|6|Trinkets}" of the {@i Player's Handbook}) and {@dice 1d4} magic items (roll on {@table Magic Item Table B} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

items.name: 18–19.
items.entry: A monster hoard containing {@dice 2d6} 50 gp gems and {@dice 1d4} magic items (roll on {@table Magic Item Table C} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).
A slain adventurer atop a monster hoard containing {@dice 3d4} 50 gp gems and {@dice 1d4} magic items (roll on {@table Magic Item Table D} in chapter 7 on the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

footnotes.name: Travellers
entries: The characters encounter one or more travellers (use the {@creature commoner} stat block) with a tale to tell:

entries.name: Road/Trail
entries: Either of the following:

items: {@dice 3d6} peasants fleeing their homes after a pirate raid or sea spawn attack.
An angry mob of {@dice 6d6} peasants looking to reclaim their land or avenge loved ones.
A lone merchant or minstrel in a horse-drawn {@item wagon|phb} who is relocating to a safer settlement

footnotes.name: Wolves
entries: The party encounter a pack of {@dice 1d6 + 5} {@creature wolf|mm|wolves}.

entries.name: Night
entries: The {@creature wolf|mm|wolves} are hunting and attack the characters' camp. A character on watch with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 14 or higher notices the pack surveying the camp. If unnoticed, the {@creature wolf|mm|wolves} surprise the characters.

entries.name: Day
entries: The characters discover a den where the {@creature wolf|mm|wolves} are sleeping. Unless the party disguise their scent, the {@creature wolf|mm|wolves} attack their camp the following night.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are above 4th level, the pack is accompanied by {@dice 1d3} {@creature dire wolf|mm|dire wolves}.

footnotes.name: Coelenites
entries: The characters are attacked by {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) who try and pull them down into the water and drown them. The {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} try to avoid leaving the ocean if possible but foray onto the shore or climb aboard boats to pursue their prey.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are 4th level or higher, replace one of the {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} with a {@creature coelenite mass mind|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). The {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} telepathically threaten the characters with drowning unless they provide a tribute of food. The {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} can be appeased with food (four day's supply per coelenite in the group). Otherwise, they attack.

footnotes.name: Dolphins
entries: The characters spot a pod of {@dice 3d4} {@creature dolphin|vgm|dolphins} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). If the characters are above the surface of the water, they notice the beautiful creatures leaping between the waves. They are naturally inquisitive and might come within 10 feet of the boat to take a look.

A {@creature dolphin|vgm} that is successfully {@condition grappled}, caught in a {@item net|phb}, or otherwise prevented from escaping can be trained as a mount by a character with proficiency in {@skill Animal Handling} who spends a few hours a day working with the mammal. At the end of 1 week, the character makes a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check. On a success, the dolphin becomes a willing mount for any humanoid.

entries.name: Sea
entries: If this encounter occurs at sea, the characters encounter {@dice 3d6} friendly sea elf {@creature scout|mm|scouts}. These elves might be from Tir faoi Thoinn, Iumathiashae, or Waterdeep. They know the location of all the Island Kingdoms and underwater locations. Characters can hire a sea elf guide for 1 gp a day.

There is a {@chance 10} chance that one of the aquatic elves is a {@creature malenti|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}); a sahuagin born with a mutation that makes it resemble an aquatic elf. The malenti spies on the characters as best it can and reports back to its sahuagin allies when it can about their movements and plans. This information eventually makes its way to the Colony of Zellix'Phor and could be used to set up an ambush with one of the mind flayers when the characters made port.

footnotes.name: Floating Debris
entries: The characters notice something floating one hundred feet away. A successful DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check reveals the nature of the debris. Roll a {@dice d6}:

items.name: 1–3.
entries: Barrels and crates.

items.name: 4–5.
entries: Shattered wooden planks.
Chests.

entries.name: Barrels and Crates
entries: Bobbing on the waves are {@dice 4d4} crates and {@item barrel|phb|barrels} filled with goods. These may contain alcohol, {@item rations (1 day)|phb|rations}, rope or other basic items typically found aboard ships.

entries.name: Shattered Wooden Planks
entries: Planks of shattered wood float atop the ocean. Clearly, these are remnants of a ship which has been recently attacked and perhaps destroyed. There is a {@chance 50} chance that a pirate ship is nearby (see "Pirate Ship" in this section).

entries.name: Chests
entries: Mostly sunk beneath the water's surface are {@dice 1d4} {@item chest|phb|chests}. These must have been jettisoned from another vessel. The {@item chest|phb|chests} are locked and keyless and require a successful DC 14 Dexterity check with {@item thieves' tools|phb} or a successful DC 16 Strength check to open. Inside are valuable items worth 100 gp, such as money, gems, candlesticks, jewellery and the like. There is a {@chance 10} chance that the chest contains a more expensive item worth 250 gp, such as a gemstone or {@table 250 gp art objects|dmg|art object}. This could be replaced with a magic item (roll once on {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

footnotes.name: Ghost Ship
entries: A merchant ship appears on the horizon but appears to be drifting very slowly. A successful DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check reveals that the deck is empty, and the ship appears to be adrift.

If the characters decide to board the ship, they discover that it is entirely empty. There is a {@chance 50} chance that they can salvage useful items from the vessel such as {@item rations (1 day)|phb|rations}, alcohol, rope and the like.

entries.name: Haunted
entries: There is a {@chance 50} chance that the ship is haunted by the dead crew. If so, there are {@dice 3d4} {@creature ghost|mm|ghosts} aboard the ship who lash out at characters that disrespect the ship by stealing, breaking into cabins etc. If characters can calm the ghosts by offering them eternal rest, they reveal that their ship was attacked by mutated pirates. They had piscine features, such as shark jaws, crab claws, and pufferfish spines. Any of the crew who resisted the creatures were killed and those who remain were taken aboard as hostages.

entries.name: Repeat
entries: If this encounter occurs again, consider replacing the {@creature ghost|mm|ghosts} with {@creature specter|mm|specters} or {@creature poltergeist|mm|poltergeists} who cannot be brought to an eternal rest.

footnotes.name: Giant Crab
entries: A {@creature giant crab} scuttles out from a kelp forest or coastal cave and attacks a random character. The target is surprised unless they have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 14 or higher. The crab attempts to {@action grapple} the character, then drop overboard with them and drown them (see "{@book Suffocating|phb|8|Suffocating|0}" in chapter 8 of the {@i Player's Handbook}). If the encounter occurs at sea, the crab claws its way up the hull to ambush the character.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are above 4th level, consider using a {@creature hulking crab|SKT} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}).

footnotes.name: Giant Shark
entries: A {@creature giant shark} surges through the water toward the party and attacks a random character. The size of the creature makes it impossible to miss, and the characters each have a turn to try and flee or {@action hide} before it arrives and attacks. Giant sharks are 30 feet long and utterly fearless.

entries.name: Ships
entries: If this encounter occurs while the characters are on a ship, the giant shark attacks whatever vessel the characters are on. These enormous fish are capable of sinking smaller ships but are just as likely to ram larger ones to try and knock unsuspecting crew overboard. If the shark rams the ship, and characters on deck must make a DC 16 Dexterity saving throw or be thrown overboard.

footnotes.name: Harpies
entries: A beautiful song carries in on the wind toward the party. Flying toward them are {@dice 1d4 + 2} {@creature harpy|mm|harpies}. As soon as the {@creature harpy|mm|harpies} are within 300 feet, they use their luring song to try and charm the characters. The {@creature harpy|mm|harpies} attempt to lure any enthralled characters into dangerous terrain such as scree slopes or overboard a ship. {@creature Harpy|mm|Harpies} might also pair up to {@action grapple} a character and fly off with them to their lair. {@creature Harpy|mm|Harpies} typically lair in isolated caves accessible only by climbing, such as rocky outcroppings, clifftops or skerries.

entries.name: Treasure
